summary: This document is a chain of internal DOJ emails from June 7-8, 2020, discussing press inquiries about a reported Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request to the UK government to interview Prince Andrew regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The emails show DOJ officials coordinating a response and reacting to Prince Andrew's legal team's public statement about confidentiality.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: The Duke of York is the subject of a reported DOJ MLAT request to the UK government to force him to answer questions in the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Kadhim Shubber
persons.context: A Financial Times reporter who sent the initial press query to the DOJ's Office of Public Affairs, asking for confirmation and comment on the report about the MLAT request regarding Prince Andrew.

connections.description: The MLAT request is part of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein, seeking to question Prince Andrew about his links to Epstein.

events.title: Press report on MLAT request for Prince Andrew
events.description: British media, specifically The Sun, reports that the DOJ issued an MLAT request to the UK last month regarding Prince Andrew to force him to answer questions in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Prince Andrew's legal team statement
events.description: Prince Andrew's legal team releases a statement reacting to the disclosure of the MLAT request, citing DOJ confidentiality rules and stating they have chosen to abide by them.

events.title: DOJ internal coordination on press response
events.description: DOJ officials internally discuss the press queries and Prince Andrew's team's statement, considering whether to clarify matters on or off the record.

keyFacts: The U.S. Department of Justice made a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request to the UK government regarding Prince Andrew in the Epstein investigation.
Prince Andrew's legal team publicly responded to the MLAT disclosure by citing DOJ confidentiality rules, claiming they have 'chosen to abide by both the letter and the spirit of these rules.'
DOJ's Office of Public Affairs was receiving numerous press inquiries about the MLAT request and was coordinating an internal response.
The reported MLAT request aimed to 'force [Prince Andrew] to answer questions' about his links to Jeffrey Epstein.
The DOJ's standard policy, as referenced in the emails, is not to publicly comment on communications with foreign governments on investigative matters.
